title: Places to Try
name: Places to Try
description:
A Map by Drmoldawer

These are restaurants I've seen or heard about and intend to visit, one of these days...

properties.name: Antique Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 55 W 26th St, New York, nyLooks cute, business lunch appropriate.

properties.name: Bouley Bakery & Market
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer120 West Broadway, New York, NYLovely two-story market, very bright and rustic. I think you can eat dinner upstairs, but I\'ll have to investigate that.

properties.name: Brooklyn Label Co.
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer180 Franklin St., brooklyn, nysupposed to have a good brunch

properties.name: Brown Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 61 Hester St., New York, NYNew cafe on the LES. I saw a photo of Gary Shteyngart eating there, so naturally I want to check it out. Seems to have a crunchy, organic vibe.

properties.name: Cafe Angelique
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 68 Bleecker St, New YorkNice little French pastry place

properties.name: Cafe Regular
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer  318 11th St, 11215Small, European-style cafe in Park Slope. Recommended by a friend. Worth a visit.

properties.name: Cafe Sabarsky at Neue Gallerie
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 1048 Fifth Avenue, new york, nyThe museum’s Café, which bears the name of Neue Galerie co-founder Serge Sabarsky, draws its inspiration from the great Viennese cafés that served as important centers of intellectual and artistic life at the turn of the century. Operated by Kurt Gutenbrunner, chef and owner of the renowned restaurant Wallsé, Café Sabarsky serves authentic Viennese specialties. The menu focuses on traditional Austrian dishes, especially fine patisserie, such as strudel and Linzertorte. The Café is outfitted with period objects, including lighting fixtures by Josef Hoffmann, furniture by Adolf Loos, and banquettes that are upholstered with a 1912 Otto Wagner fabric. A Yamaha S4 grand piano graces one corner of the Café, and is used for all cabaret and chamber music performances at the museum. It is also used for classical music in the Café on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons, as well as on Friday evenings. Hours: Monday, Wednesday 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. Closed Tuesday

properties.name: Chestnut
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer271 Smith Street, new york, nySupposed to be a great Italian restaurant in Carroll Gardens.

properties.name: Florencia 13
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer185 Sullivan St, new york, nyLooks like a great Mexican restaurant with a funky, West Coast vibe. I need to check it out.

properties.name: Fragole
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer394 Court, brooklyn, nyRecommended as a good Italian place near Frankie 457 in Carroll Gardens.

properties.name: Frankie's 17
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer17 Clinton St, New York, NYManhattan version of the great Carroll Gardens panini place. Can\'t wait to try it.

properties.name: Kalustyan's
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer123 Lexington Ave, new york, nyTry this Mediterranean sandwich shop, and ask for Silva\'s friend, Arpiar.

properties.name: Kyotofu
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer705 Ninth Avenue, new york, ny"Hey gang, let\'s all go uptown for some tofu!" may be the least-inviting come-on in New York. (Runner-up: "Let\'s meet on the No. 6 train at 5 p.m.") But, says Peter Meehan, "anyone who detours to Kyotofu will be rewarded with desserts executed with the precision one expects from a four-star kitchen." The soy-based goodies, like sansho pepper tofu cheesecake, and sweet tofu, "a helping of quivering, creamy goodness," are served in a pseudo-futuristic dining room, with far-out cocktails to match. Eating there, Mr. Meehan says, is like being in a "dessert-fueled spaceship." Mmmmm, the future. Kyotofu, 705 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), (212) 974-6012.

properties.name: Lamarca
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer161 E 22ND St, new york, nyI\'ve heard this place has fantastic pasta. The ambience isn\'t great, it\'s pretty unassuming, but it looks perfect for a casual meal with friends. Very affordable, too.

properties.name: Portfolio Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 4 W 19th St, new york, nyLooks like a decent Italian place. Appropriate for business lunches. Medium prices.

properties.name: Rosa Mexicano
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer9 East 18th Street, new york, nyFancy, trendy Mexican. Good for business. Make reservations.

properties.name: Soy Luck Club
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer  115 greenwich ave, new york, nyCute little cafe with free wifi.

properties.name: Sullivan Diner
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer 169 Sullivan St, new york, nyLooks like a nice, upscale, hipster diner. Worth checking out.

properties.name: Sushi Samba
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer245 Park Ave S, New York, NYGood sushi and Spanish fusion. A bit pricey, but a nice place for a business lunch.

properties.name: Vietnam Bánh Mì Sổ 1
properties.description: Posted by Drmoldawer369 Broome St, New York, NYRecommended as a sandwich shop that used to be a secret, but it\'s so good it got renovated.
